tn.text: These verses are exactly the same as [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:06|01:6-7]] and can probably be translated in the same way.
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:06|01:6]].
This is not a specific day. The gathering happened often. AT: "at the time when" or "one day when"
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:06|01:6]].
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:06|01:6]].

tn.ref: From wandering on the earth, from going  back and forth on it
tn.text: Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:06|01:7]].
This verse is the same as [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:06|1:8]], except for the addition of "He still holds fast to his integrity, although you misled me against him, to destroy him without cause."

tn.ref: Have you considered my servant Job?
tn.text: This rhetorical question actually makes a statement .Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:06|1:8]]. AT: "Consider my servant Job." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]).
Translate this as you did a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: one who fears God and turns away from evil
tn.text: Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:01|1:1]].

tn.ref: still holds fast to his integrity
tn.text: "remains completely dedicated to doing what is good and right"
"persuaded me without cause to attack him"
Here "destroy" represents "make poor." AT: "to make him a poor man"
"Skin" is a metonym for Job's life. AT: "A person will do anything to save his own life, even accept the loss of possessions and loved ones." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: But stretch out your hand now and touch his bones and his flesh, and see if he does not curse you to your face
tn.text: Satan means that if God attacks Job, he will see how Job responds. AT: "But now, if you stretch out your hand and touch his bones and his flesh, you will see that he will curse you to your face"
Here "hand" refers to God's power to act. "But now use your power." Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:09|01:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "touch" represents the action of harming. AT: "attack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This expression represents Job's body. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:09|01:11]].
This refers to a time when God is paying attention. AT: "in your hearing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Then Satan went away from the presence of Yahweh
tn.text: Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:09|1:12]].
"attacked" or "afflicted with"
large, itching and painful skin infections

tn.ref: a piece of broken pottery to scrape himself
tn.text: The scraping scratches the skin to lessen the itch.

tn.ref: sat down in the middle of ashes
tn.text: This probably refers to a place where trash and garbage were dumped and perhaps burned. Sitting in such a place was a sign of deep mourning. AT: "sat on the trash heap" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: Do you still hold fast to your integrity?
tn.text: This rhetorical question represents a statement. AT: "You should not still be holding fast to your integrity." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"Reject God"

tn.ref: You talk as a foolish woman
tn.text: Job is saying she talks like a fool. AT: "You talk as if you were a stupid woman."

tn.ref: Should we receive the good from God and not receive the bad?
tn.text: This rhetorical question represents a statement. AT: "We should certainly receive the bad from God as well as the good." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"benefit from all the good things"
This represents all the good things that God gives us. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_genericnoun]])
"suffer all the bad things without complaining"
This represents all the bad things that God makes or allows us to experience. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_genericnoun]])
Here "lips" represents the act of speaking. AT: "sin by speaking against God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite
tn.text: Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar are men's names. Teman was a city in Edom. Shuhites are the decedents of Abraham and Keturah (see Genesis [[:en:bible:notes:gen:25:01|25:1]]). Naamah was a city in Canaan. (See: [[ en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"agreed on a time"

tn.ref: to mourn with him and to comfort him
tn.text: Here the words "mourn with" and "comfort" share similar meanings. The friends try to comfort Job by mourning with him. AT: "to grieve with Job in order to help ease his suffering." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"they looked intently" or "they looked carefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This probably means that Job's visitors did not recognize him at first, when they saw him at a distance. Job looked very different than usual because of his grief and because of the sores covering his body. AT: "they barely recognized him"

tn.ref: they raised their voices and wept
tn.text: "they wept out loud" or "they wept loudly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This was a sign of mourning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: threw dust into the air and upon his own head
tn.text: These were signs of mourning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
